Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: A large decline of tropospheric NO<sub>2</sub> in China observed from space by SNPP OMPS.

AbstractText: Nitrogen oxides (NO<sub>x</sub>) are important constituents of air pollution. Here we use retrievals of tropospheric NO<sub>2</sub> column from the Ozone Mapping Profiler Suite (OMPS) Nadir Mapper (NM) onboard the Suomi National Polar Partnership (SNPP) spacecraft to analyze global changes of NO<sub>2</sub> from 2012 to 2017. The largest decline of NO<sub>2</sub> is detected in eastern China, at a rate of -7.3 ± 1.5% per year, and almost entirely driven by wintertime decreases, indicative of decreasing anthropogenic NO<sub>x</sub> emissions. During the same period, NO<sub>2</sub> over other regions around the globe was either stabilizing or changing at a rate only a fraction of that in China. In the case of the US, OMPS reports a statistically insignificant decreasing trend in NO<sub>2</sub>, consistent with recent work based on the Ozone Monitoring Instrument (OMI), which can be almost entirely attributed to meteorology. OMPS thus offers a continuation of satellite NO<sub>2</sub> products from OMI to future JPSS satellites.
